title: How did the New World benefit from the Columbian Exchange? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Spaniards discovered here in America mainly tomatoes and beans from nowadays Mexico (New Spain at that time), cocoa / chocolate in Central America (current Nicaragua, but natives consumed it mixed with chile and not sweetened with sugar), potatoes in peruvian zone, tobacco and corn. All of them were sent to be introduced and cultivated in Europe. Spanish people introduced: Roman plow in these latitudes and trained natives to use it.The wheel and carts, that natives did not know.Pulleys, hoists and cranes to move large weights.They introduce iron, muffle furnaces, forges, bellows, tempered steel and wood sawsFinally for agriculture it is also very important to remind that spanish brought oxen, donkeys, mules and horses (Mustang horses are descendants of Iberian horses that were brought to the Americas by explorers). This circumstance had a consequence of freeing slaves (macehuales) from being used as beasts of burden.As for food and livestock, the exchange was fundamental, but what was introduced in this continent was much greater than what they took from America to Europe. Spain brought to America most of grains used today: wheat (obviously bread too), rice which now it is probably the most eaten grain, barley, oatmeal, Most of nuts: walnuts, hazelnuts, almonds Most of vegetables: lentils, sweetpeas, greenpeas, leaks, carrots, beets, turnips, radishes, cabbage, cauliflower, spinach, chards Most of fruits: Bananas, strawberries, apples, pears, cherries, plums, figs, peach, apricots. They started growing citrus fruits: oranges, lemons and limes, which are fundamental today, but which did not exist, nor were grown in America and therefore were not consumed by Americans. Without it, fundamental ingredients would be lost in the Mexican diet or, for example, Peruvian cebiche would not exist. Vines and its obvious subproduct: wine. Most of spices: cinnamon, pepper, garlic, thyme, rosemary, lavender, bay leaf, clove, onions and other spices. Others: Sausages, chorizo, ham and any cured meats, cane sugar, olives and olive oil, coffee. Mulberry cultivation and silk production Cattle: The spanish conquerors and settlers brought and began to raise in America cows, pigs, sheeps and goats which introduced a large amount of protein in the diet of the indigenous people and help eliminate cannibalism. Subproduct of cows and sheep, spanish introduced milk, cheeses and other dairy products in this continent. Chicken also did not existed in America and spanish brought them, as eggs, obviously. Spain got from America turkey (it was called “american chicken”) and introduced it in Europe. They introduced beekeeping The making of wax candles that replace torches. Woven and woolen garments, the production and tundido of cloths using hydraulic wheels, etc., etc. They introduced crossbows, swords, horse riding, gunpowder, artillery, compass, the manufacture of sailing ships, rudder and rowing (brigs) and the art of handling them, wood-cutting saws, shipyards, the construction of navigation canals, the Roman arch, domes, hallways, windows, hinged doors, locks, etc. They introduce the mines, of gold, silver, lead, hematite, etc. and the "benefit" of mercury-based amalgam for the extraction of silver from the ore. The paper, the writing of the indigenous terms in the Latin alphabet, the handwritten and printed books, the dictionaries and grammar in indigenous languages, the teaching to the indigenous of Latin and European painting, sculpture, poetry and music, teaching of pottery , blown glass, adobe (of Arabic origin), carpentry and joinery, leatherwork, tanning of leather, goldsmiths, and other arts and crafts; They introduced dozens of grammars of indigenous languages, such as Nahuatl, which are still used today. Dozens of universities and hospitals. Below, Universities  So Spain and spanish people were the vehicle to interchange every product between Europe and America, but the contribution from Europe was far superior than viceversa

The exchange, of course, includes the indigenous peoples of the Americas. Relatively speaking, any benefits for them were completely overshadowed by a few stark facts. Ninety-nine percent of them perished from the diseases brought over by the first explorers. After that, they were enslaved, slaughtered and their land was taken. Benefits for the explorers, colonists, European regimes and European entrepreneurs were inestimable. Billions of dollars worth of gold and silver crossed the Atlantic to Europe. Trade enriched all parties. There were tremendous advances in science and technology stimulated by the problems of exploration and settlement. Relief was provided for thousands escaping poverty and religious persecution. Power and prestige was vastly increased for European imperialists. Important foods had a significant impact in reducing food scarcity in Europe. Many new nations were ultimately able to advance their own self-determination, free of European control. Settlers of the new world, mostly, thrived and prospered.
